results.title: Short of Prison Space, U.K. Looks to U.S. Model of Time Off for Good Conduct
results.abstract: An official review commissioned by the British government calls for criminals to earn earlier release, and cites Texas as a particular example.

multimedia.caption: The Wandsworth prison in London, which a report found to be overcrowded and infested with vermin last year.

results.title: Israeli Soldiers Fire at Diplomats in West Bank
results.abstract: A group of Western diplomats were touring Jenin, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, on Wednesday when Israeli soldiers fired at least seven shots to disperse the visiting officials.

results.title: Israeli Soldiers Fire in Air to Disperse Western Diplomats in West Bank
results.abstract: The event in Jenin, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, came amid rising tensions between Israel and its foreign partners.

results.title: He’s a Heavy Metal Musician, and Taiwan’s New Envoy to Finland
results.abstract: Freddy Lim, the founder and lead singer of Chthonic, is well known in Finland, a heavy metal capital of the world.

multimedia.caption: Freddy Lim, who was appointed as Taiwan’s envoy to Finland on Monday, performing with his band, Chthonic, in Tokyo in 2019.

results.title: German Police Arrest Five Teenagers in Domestic Terrorism Raid
results.abstract: The group planned and carried out arson attacks on buildings housing asylum seekers, authorities said, warning that far-right extremist organizations are increasingly attracting young people.
results.byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Christopher F. Schuetze

multimedia.caption: “This is a warning sign and shows that right-wing extremist terrorism knows no age,” Stefanie Hubig, Germany’s justice minister, said in a statement on social media.

results.title: Gunmen Kill Former Ukrainian Politician in Spain
results.abstract: Andriy Portnov was a senior aide to Ukraine’s former president Viktor F. Yanukovych, who was ousted in a 2014 uprising over his alignment with Moscow.
results.byline: By Maria Varenikova and José Bautista

results.title: Pope Leo XIV Calls for Aid to Enter Gaza
results.abstract: Calling the hunger crisis in the war-torn territory “heart-rending,” the pope used his first general audience to highlight the issue.

results.title: India’s Security Forces Kill Dozens in a Bid to Crush Leftist Rebels
results.abstract: Military operations have intensified in recent weeks as the government has set a deadline of next year to defeat a decades-old Maoist insurgency.

multimedia.caption: Members of the District Reserve Guard at their base in Dantewada in Chhattisgarh state in India. The country’s security forces have recently escalated their campaign to eliminate leftist militants.

results.title: Chris Brown Released on $6 Million Bail by London Court
results.abstract: The R&B singer was charged last week with grievous bodily harm over a 2023 incident in England. His release from custody means he can proceed with a world tour.

results.title: E.U. Offers Emergency Funding for Radio Free Europe After Trump Cuts
results.abstract: The European Union said it would provide short-term financing for Radio Free Europe, but the amount falls short of what the news outlet says it needs to stay afloat.

multimedia.caption: The headquarters of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty in Prague, Czech Republic, earlier this year. President Trump has ordered the dismantling of the news outlet’s parent company.

results.title: School Bus Bombing in Pakistan Kills at Least 6, Including 4 Students
results.abstract: The vehicle was carrying dozens of children to a military-run school in southwestern Balochistan Province, a region long roiled by rebel activity.

results.title: Hong Kong’s Beleaguered Journalists Say Their Taxes Are Now Under Scrutiny
results.abstract: Several news outlets have been unreasonably subjected to tax investigations, according to the city’s journalists’ association, adding to pressures on press freedom.

results.title: Putin Visits Kursk for First Time Since Russia Drove Out Ukrainian Forces
results.abstract: The Russian leader traveled to the region in the west of the country where a surprise incursion last year embarrassed Moscow.
results.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

multimedia.caption: An image released by the Kremlin on Wednesday showed President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visiting a nuclear power plant under construction in the Kursk region of the country.

results.title: Israel Said It Eased Its Blockade, But Gazans Are Still Waiting for Food
results.abstract: Three days after Israel said it would relax its blockade of humanitarian aid to Gaza, little, if any, of the urgently needed food, fuel and medicine appeared to have reached Palestinians.
results.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Bilal Shbair and Iyad Abuheweila

results.title: Iran Executes Man Over Deadly 2023 Attack on Azerbaijan Embassy
results.abstract: The killing of the embassy’s head of security strained an already tense relationship between the neighboring countries.
results.byline: By Leily Nikounazar and Qasim Nauman

results.title: A Fábrica de Espiões
results.abstract: A inteligência russa transformou o Brasil em uma linha de montagem de espiões. Mas policiais federais brasileiros trabalham, discretamente, para desmontá-la.
results.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Jane Bradley, Lucy Jones and Dado Galdieri

multimedia.caption: Seis espiões russos, no sentido horário, a partir do canto superior esquerdo: Yekaterina Leonidovna Danilova, Vladimir Aleksandrovich Danilov, Olga Igorevna Tyutereva, Aleksandr Andreyevich Utekhin, Irina Alekseyevna Antonova e Roman Olegovich Koval.

results.title: Text Messages Between Russian Spies, Annotated
results.abstract: The messages offer a glimpse at life deep undercover. Our correspondents break down four revealing exchanges.
results.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Jane Bradley

results.title: When the U.S. and Israel Bomb the Houthis, Civilians Pay the Highest Price
results.abstract: Military strikes in Yemen and sanctions targeting the Iran-backed militia have compounded a humanitarian crisis in the poorest country in the Middle East, officials say.
results.byline: By Ismaeel Naar and Saeed Al-Batati

multimedia.caption: A building in Sana, Yemen, damaged by U.S. airstrikes in April. Aid agencies say that the bombing campaigns have caused more harm to civilians than the Houthis.

results.title: The Spy Factory
results.abstract: Russia’s intelligence services turned Brazil into an assembly line for deep-cover operatives. A team of federal agents from the South American country has been quietly dismantling it.
results.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Jane Bradley, Lucy Jones and Dado Galdieri

results.title: Japanese Farm Minister Resigns After Saying He’d Never Bought Rice
results.abstract: The remark came in the midst of a rice shortage that has infuriated voters. “Frankly, my supporters give me quite a lot of rice,” said the minister, Taku Eto.

multimedia.caption: Taku Eto, Japan’s agriculture minister, after meeting with Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba in Tokyo on Monday. Mr. Eto’s remark about rice created a furor ahead of a national election in July.
